examples.company:
YouTube Kids
  - Parental Gate Math Challenge
examples.title:
Before
  accessing settings or external links, child is shown a simple arithmetic
  puzzle that an adult can solve quickly; prevents accidental navigation.
examples.use_case:
COPPA‑compliant
  kids’ video platform limiting under‑13 autonomy.
examples.why_selected:
Demonstrates
  low‑friction yet effective adult verification without personal data
  collection.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Error
  prevention; Match between system & real world

examples.title:
When
  child (<13) requests an app, parent receives approval prompt on their
  device; purchase held until approved.
examples.use_case:
Preventing
  unauthorized downloads & data collection from minors.
examples.why_selected:
Asynchronous,
  device‑linked guardian approval flow aligned with parental consent
  requirements.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
User
  control & freedom; Visibility of system status

examples.title:
Users
  enter government ID + selfie for 13+ voice chat; optional 4‑digit PIN locks
  account settings for kids.
examples.use_case:
Metaverse
  platform with UGC; must segregate adult features.
examples.why_selected:
Combines
  biometric ID verification with PIN‑guarded settings, balancing access &
  safety.

Shows dual-layer: initial age gate plus ongoing guardianship
  controls.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Aesthetic
  & minimalist design; Help users recognize, diagnose, recover

examples.title:
Children’s
  accounts governed by guardian dashboard: approve app installs, set bedtimes,
  view activity. Age gating on app content ratings.
examples.why_selected:
Illustrates
  integrated, cross‑device parental consent and monitoring flow.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Recognition
  rather than recall; Flexibility & efficiency

examples.title:
Lean
  modal with two equal‑weight CTAs: “Share” and “No Thanks”; default is off
  unless actively enabled.
examples.use_case:
Privacy‑centric
  messaging app deciding on optional telemetry.
examples.why_selected:
Illustrates
  symmetrical choice, neutral language, and no-preselected option—avoids
  coercive consent.
examples.pbd_alignment:
Privacy
  as default, Respect for user privacy
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
User
  control & freedom; Aesthetic & minimalist design

examples.title:
Banner
  offers “Reject All” and “Accept All” buttons side‑by‑side in identical
  styling; granular controls via link.
examples.use_case:
Large
  media site complying with UK ICO guidance.
examples.why_selected:
Demonstrates
  equal effort choices, countering “confirmshaming”
  dark patterns.

examples.title:
Two‑step
  process: Account ▸ Cancel
  Membership leads to confirmation page with single
  “Finish Cancellation” button; no hidden hurdles.
examples.why_selected:
Showcases
  straightforward off‑boarding without salvage offers that delay exit—aligns
  with FTC “Click to Cancel” proposal.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Flexibility
  & efficiency; Help users recognize, diagnose, recover

examples.title:
Standard
  system sheet: “Ask App Not to Track” option presented first, bolded equally
  to “Allow”. App cannot customise copy beyond purpose string.
examples.why_selected:
ATT
  enforces balanced choice architecture via OS, preventing deceptive delays or microcopy.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Error
  prevention; Visibility of system status

examples.title:
Recognised
  marketing emails show “Unsubscribe” link in header next to sender; removes
  need to search footer.
examples.why_selected:
Reduces
  friction and eliminates misleading unsubscribe pages—example of “easy exit”
  principle.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Recognition
  rather than recall; User control & freedom

examples.title:
“Delete
  activity by” dialog (date range / service), plus Auto‑Delete schedules
  (3/18/36 months). History list shows past deletions.
examples.use_case:
Users
  controlling search, location, YouTube history.
examples.why_selected:
Combines
  on‑demand deletion, scheduled purging, and visible audit, aligning with GDPR
  Art. 7(3) & 17.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
User
  control & freedom; Recognition rather than recall

examples.title:
Dashboard
  lists third‑party data received; single‑tap “Clear History” + toggle “Future
  Activity”. Timestamped log provides evidence of withdrawal.
examples.use_case:
Social
  platforms processing external browsing data.
examples.why_selected:
Shows
  comprehensive background data view with one‑click revoke & future
  blocking.
examples.pbd_alignment:
End‑to-End
  security, Respect for user privacy
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Visibility
  of system status; Flexibility & efficiency

examples.title:
List of
  ad interactions and inferred interests; “Clear History” and toggle sharing
  with partners.
examples.why_selected:
Provides
  granular revoke & clear with explanatory tooltips—avoids dark patterns.
examples.nielsen_heuristics:
Aesthetic
  & minimalist design; Help users recognize, diagnose, recover

examples.title:
Workspace
  Settings list OAuth‑authorized apps/bots; each row has “Remove” + timestamp
  of grant.
examples.use_case:
SaaS
  collaboration where third‑party integrations access messages.
examples.why_selected:
Demonstrates
  transparent grant history and instant token revoke for enterprise compliance.
